Text saved: The “buy nothing” trend has now reached influencers, who are people that share ideas with many followers on social media, and who usually post about clothing and make‑up that they recommend to buy. However, some YouTube stars now encourage their viewers not to buy anything for periods as long as a year. Two friends in Canada spent a year trying to buy only food. For the first three months they learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes or other things for the house, and they found simple ways to reuse what they already had. In the next stage they gave up services, such as haircuts, eating out at restaurants or buying petrol for their cars, because they wanted to keep their spending low. After one year they had saved $55,000.

Second, the output adds a reason for their actions by stating they gave up services 'because they wanted to keep their spending low'. The original text does not provide this reason. Simplification must not involve adding new facts or inferring motives. Despite this critical error, the submission did successfully define the keyword 'influencers' and met the B1 CEFR target as well as the MeaningBERT and BERTScore thresholds. To fix this, remove all information that was not explicitly stated in the original text.
